p.s: Description of the order Prochlorales ord. nov., nom. rev.
Prochlorales (Pro.chlo.ra'les. M .L. fem. n. Prochloraceae type family of order; ales ending to denote an order; M.L. fem. pl. n. Prochlorales the Prochloraceae order)
Cells are unicellular or multicellular gram-negative photosynthetic procaryotes, containing chlorophylls a and b and carotenoids.
Motile or nonmotile, Free living or symbionts on invertebrate animals (didemnid ascidians, sponges, or tectibranch molluscs).
The photopigments are located on paired (not single) thylakoids without phycobilisomes.
The arrangement of DNA, scattered in the periphery of the cell (therefore the center appears hollow), is different from that of all the cyanobacteria (6).
The cells do not contain gas vacuoles or cyanophicin.

This broad definition of the ordinal rank is made not to restrict Prochlorales solely to the photosynthetic procaryotes having a proven symbiotic capacity in a given host, but to make possible the inclusion of free-living members, which can be cultivated away from the host.
